Situation1: They oversee multiple teams, resolving conflicts and delays to ensure a critical project meets a strict deadline.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A client quietly shares a private concern while filling out forms at the check-in table.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, phone buzzing with urgent messages from the construction site. As the lead architect, I was expected to keep everything on track—no delays, no excuses. The project was already behind, and my team looked to me to resolve every hiccup. My mind raced with solutions when my volunteer shift at the community center began. I barely had time to switch gears before a woman approached the check-in table, her hands trembling as she filled out the forms. She leaned in, voice barely above a whisper, and confided a personal concern, trusting me to keep it private. My phone vibrated again—another crisis at the site. I felt torn, the weight of my professional responsibilities pressing against the trust this woman placed in me. I knew both roles demanded my full attention, but the expectations seemed impossible to reconcile. My heart pounded as I sat between two worlds, unsure which to answer first.
